Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated Design of Ultrahigh Surface Area Conductive Materials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Porous materials have great potential in a number of applications, but many challenges exist in the synthesis and manufacturing of high surface-area porous materials that can operate at high temperatures and conduct electricity. This award supports research aiming to integrate theory, experiment, and computational simulations to understand and enable a new class of high temperature stable and ultrahigh surface area porous materials known as silicon oxycarbides (SiOC). Such porous materials have exciting applications in catalysis, gas separation, sensing, electrodes, molecular sieves, thermal insulation, and micro-reactors. Their high thermal stability will enable new applications under harsh conditions where traditional materials have failed. The program integrates multi-layered education and outreach activities and will provide training to multiple graduate and undergraduate students, in materials experimental and simulation research and across two university campuses.
Â 
This project is aimed at understanding the relationship between the composition and structure of SiOC materials, and the potential for synthesizing materials with high surface area, high temperature stability, and high electrical conductivity. The team will create nanosized pores and domains by tailoring polymer precursors, as well as tailoring crosslinking and pyrolysis conditions. By selective removal of phase-separated species, the approach will provide ultrahigh surface area and high temperature stable materials with <5 nm pores and much desired electrical conductivity. Multi-scale atomistic modeling (ab-initio and large-scale molecular dynamics) will couple to experiment and provide insight in bonding characteristics at interfaces between different phases, driving forces for phase segregation, the evolution of the graphitic substructure, as well as macroscopic properties governed at the nanoscale. A coarse-grain model will combine experimental and computational data and provide an unprecedented and unique platform to model and design the polymer-to-ceramic transformation and post-pyrolysis treatment. This research will establish a new paradigm in molecular design and processing of ultrahigh surface area, high temperature materials with electrical conductivity beyond SiOC, such as SiCN, SiOCN, SiBCN, SiOBC, SiAlCN, and SiAlOC.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
We describe two major outcomes of this research project: development and application of Differential Hysteresis Scanningas a tool to study connectivity of pores in SiCO aerogels, and computational exploration of the genesis of carbon segregations in SiCO ceramics and the impact these hahave on properties.

We develop and apply Differential Hysteresis Scanning (DHS) porosimetry for amorphous porous SiCO. DHS augments and complements information from electron microscopy and "standard" porosimetry. Our method provides a more detailed description of hierarchical interconnections of pores, as 

  • we deliver two-dimensional (2D) contour plots characterizing the relation between the diameter of a pore and the size of its connected window. 

This technology, in conjunction with other assessments, reveals the significant changes occurring in pore and surface characteristics resulting from modifications of kinetics and thermodynamics in synthesis and subsequent processing. Specifically, we illustrate how 

  • a mono-dispersed pore hierarchy in SiCO aerogels is obtained after synthesis in cyclohexane and annealing at 1000?C: pores 41 nm wide connected via 13 nm windows.

Knowledge of the hierarchical structure will assist in meeting the design requirements for diverse applications, notably in control of surface heterogeneity, localization, and sequential accessibility. The two-dimensional porosity characterization, for example, is a tool to support tailored synthesis of new materials with large cavities and small access windows. These can provide space for encapsulation of substrates and catalysts or for storage and controlled release of chemical compounds.

 

Our computational work delivered 

  • a new reactive force field (ReaxFF) for simulations of the thermal conversion of polysiloxanes, polymer precursors to SiCO ceramics. 

The force field comes with accuracy comparable to electronic structure methods but at a fraction of their costs. We used this approach and performed extensive MD simulations of structure formation in SiCO ceramics. Combining different methods reveals the 

  • genesis of carbon segregations in SiCO containing "free" carbon.

a. During synthesis, single-layer graphene forms inside amorphous SiCO ceramics.

b. these layers either persist or coil up to form tubular structures, a process that depends on the composition of the surrounding matrix

Simulations of pyrolysis processes of polysiloxanes show the segregation of excess carbon as a common feature occurring during the polymer-to-ceramic conversion. The formation of single-layer graphene has significant impact on materials properties. We relate the unusually high Li storage capacity of SiCO ceramics with "free" carbon to their "nano domain" structure. 

  • graphene layers facilitate formation of thin SiCO glass domains which store Li 

The particular carbon morphology in SiCO, whether dispersed, graphene, tubular, or large graphite-like segregation also affects its mechanical properties. 

  • Carbon morphology is an independent variable in SiCO besides density and composition and may cause 25% of difference in mechanical properties of SiCO.

Overall, we learn that SiCO is a fascinating material which has many different facets worthy for continuing and future exploration.

 


Last Modified: 10/04/2020
Modified by: Peter Kroll
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: We describe two major outcomes of this research project: development and application of Differential Hysteresis Scanningas a tool to study connectivity of pores in SiCO aerogels, and computational exploration of the genesis of carbon segregations in SiCO ceramics and the impact these hahave on properties. We develop and apply Differential Hysteresis Scanning (DHS) porosimetry for amorphous porous SiCO. DHS augments and complements information from electron microscopy and "standard" porosimetry. Our method provides a more detailed description of hierarchical interconnections of pores, as we deliver two-dimensional (2D) contour plots characterizing the relation between the diameter of a pore and the size of its connected window. This technology, in conjunction with other assessments, reveals the significant changes occurring in pore and surface characteristics resulting from modifications of kinetics and thermodynamics in synthesis and subsequent processing. Specifically, we illustrate how a mono-dispersed pore hierarchy in SiCO aerogels is obtained after synthesis in cyclohexane and annealing at 1000?C: pores 41 nm wide connected via 13 nm windows. Knowledge of the hierarchical structure will assist in meeting the design requirements for diverse applications, notably in control of surface heterogeneity, localization, and sequential accessibility. The two-dimensional porosity characterization, for example, is a tool to support tailored synthesis of new materials with large cavities and small access windows. These can provide space for encapsulation of substrates and catalysts or for storage and controlled release of chemical compounds. Our computational work delivered a new reactive force field (ReaxFF) for simulations of the thermal conversion of polysiloxanes, polymer precursors to SiCO ceramics. The force field comes with accuracy comparable to electronic structure methods but at a fraction of their costs. We used this approach and performed extensive MD simulations of structure formation in SiCO ceramics. Combining different methods reveals the genesis of carbon segregations in SiCO containing "free" carbon. a. During synthesis, single-layer graphene forms inside amorphous SiCO ceramics. b. these layers either persist or coil up to form tubular structures, a process that depends on the composition of the surrounding matrix Simulations of pyrolysis processes of polysiloxanes show the segregation of excess carbon as a common feature occurring during the polymer-to-ceramic conversion. The formation of single-layer graphene has significant impact on materials properties. We relate the unusually high Li storage capacity of SiCO ceramics with "free" carbon to their "nano domain" structure. graphene layers facilitate formation of thin SiCO glass domains which store Li The particular carbon morphology in SiCO, whether dispersed, graphene, tubular, or large graphite-like segregation also affects its mechanical properties. Carbon morphology is an independent variable in SiCO besides density and composition and may cause 25% of difference in mechanical properties of SiCO. Overall, we learn that SiCO is a fascinating material which has many different facets worthy for continuing and future exploration. Last Modified: 10/04/2020 Submitted by: Peter Kroll
